Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Observation and Prediction of Ocean Acidification in the Western Arctic Ocean - Impacts of Physical and Biogeochemical Processes on Carbonate Mineral States
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will assess ocean acidification in the western Arctic Ocean, using ship time that is currently scheduled for annual mooring turnarounds in the Beaufort Sea. On these cruises, in September of 2011-2013, the investigators will collect samples for measurement of carbonate system parameters, inorganic nutrients, dissolved oxygen, oxygen isotopes, and oxygen/argon ratios, as well as continuous underway measurements of dissolved oxygen, oxygen/argon ratios, and pCO2. These data will be used to gain insights and perspectives into the extent of ocean acidification in the western Arctic Ocean; the key physical, chemical, and biological processes influencing the saturation states of aragonite and calcite; and potential impacts to pelagic and benthic communities. Water column observations will be synthesized with data from the associated NSF AON (Arctic Observing Network)-funded mooring, including temperature, salinity, nitrate, oxygen, pCO2, and pH, as well as carbon and hydrographic data collected on other cruises in the region. During each field season the PI will travel to several native villages to discuss the potential impacts of ocean acidification at town meetings and in classrooms. The work will contribute to carbon cycle studies coordinated under a variety of science plans and implementation structures that aim to establish accurate estimates of carbon budgets and fluxes and the underlying mechanisms that regulate them. A postdoctoral scientist will participate directly in this work, and results will be incorporated in one undergraduate level course and two graduate level courses taught by the lead investigator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Declining sea ice extent during the Arctic summer has the potential to shift spatial patterns and timing of primary production, i.e. the growth of tiny marine plants that make up the base of Arctic food webs. This project resulted in the collection of a suite of measurements to assess the key processes influencing biological activity in the Western Arctic in late summer, when sea ice extent is near its seasonal minimum. We measured the net activity of surface biological communities by tracking the net oxygen balance in very high resolution using a relatively new approach (equilibrated inlet mass spectrometry). The net oxygen balance allows us to constrain the balance of community-level photosynthesis (growth at the bottom of the food chain) vs community respiration.  These high- resolution observations allowed us to identify biological ‘hotspots’, where growth far exceeded community respiration in some locations. Because growth is typically limited by availability of nutrients in late summer, these hotspots imply regions where nutrient supply is likely occurring. We suggest that a variety of processes, including upwelling and mixing from frequent storm activity may be important for enhancing nutrient availability during this late summer timeframe.

 

In addition, we find that areas of net oxygen production in late summer contribute appreciably to the transfer of carbon from the atmosphere into the ocean in the Pacific Arctic region. This finding should help to improve models that predict the response of this region to future warming trends. Results will also inform future studies that seek to evaluate ecosystem impacts of Arctic sea ice loss.
